results.title: Angelica Mesiti: The Calling interview
results.creator_credit: Jesse Taylorsmith, Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick, ACMI and Ian Potter Cultural Trust
results.brief_description:
In this interview (filmed as part of activities associated with the ACMI Exhibition ‘Angelica Mesiti: The Calling’) the artist reflects on the structure, approach and the processes involved in creating the work.

‘The Calling’ is a three channel video installation that focuses on whistling languages, ancient forms of non-verbal communication which are still used in 2013 to communicate in isolated and difficult landscapes.

To conduct research for ‘The Calling’, artist Angelica Mesiti travelled to the village of Kuskoy in Northern Turkey, the island of La Gomera in The Canary Islands and the Island of Evia in Greece where whistling languages are still in use.

results.title: From Jean-Paul Sartre to Teresa Teng: Cantonese Contemporary Art in the 1980s
results.creator_credit: Clair Hsu, Jane DeBevoise, Arts Asia Archive and Siren Films
results.brief_description:
Interviews with leading Cantonese artists and their memories of a developing art scene in the 1980s.

“The 1980s was a seminal period in the history of contemporary art in China. However, the contribution and experimentalism of the art scene in South China, in particular, Guangzhou and Shenzhen, have generally been overlooked. Due to the proximity of Hong Kong, western ideas from translated books and articles, as well as popular culture in the form of TV shows and Canto pop, flooded over the border to Guangdong at the end of the Cultural Revolution. This influx of new ideas and popular culture sparked great excitement, debate and experimentation in the arts.

Based on primary research, rare film footage and personal interviews with key artists, this documentary bears witness not only to the reading fever that gripped the Chinese art world in the 1980s, but also highlights the experimentalism and verve of artists and critics in South China whose contributions to the development of contemporary art have been long lasting and fundamental.” Source: Arts Asia Archive [www.aaa.org.hk]

Interviewees include: Chen Shaoxiong, Chen Tong, Deng Jianjin, Feng Yuan, Hou Hanru, Huang Xiaopeng, Li Zhengtian, Lin Yilin, Shao Hong, Wang Du, Wang Huangsheng, Xu Tan, Yang Jiechang and Yang Xiaoyan.

results.title: [Cinesound Review: Royal Tour Concludes]
results.creator_credit: William M. Carty, Cinesound and Peter Bell
results.brief_description:
This film is a Cinesound Review, a news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. The newsreel shows the final leg of the 1970 Royal Tour with Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh and Princess Anne, for the bicentenary celebrations of the arrival of Captain James Cook in Australia in 1770.

The film shows the royal family arriving in Brisbane, Queensland, on the Royal Yacht Britannia, where they are greeted by crowds of people in hundreds of boats on the river. It shows the family attending various events, including a welcome at Parliament House, theatre shows and a children’s parade at Lang Park, or Brisbane Stadium.

Princess Anne visits a sheep station at Cunnamulla, Queensland, while Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip visit the mines at Mount Isa, Queensland.

The film shows bicentenary celebrations in Cooktown, Queensland, and Botany Bay, New South Wales. These celebrations include a speech by the Queen and re-enactments of Captain James Cook’s arrival in Australia in 1770, with interactions with Aboriginal Australian people.

The film continues with fireworks over Sydney Harbour; an ANZAC Day march in Canberra, Australian Capital Territory; Prince Philip playing polo with a local team; and the opening of the international terminal at Sydney Airport, from which the royal family departs.

results.title: The Telegram Man
results.creator_credit: James Khehtie, Ceinwen Berry and Victoria Wharfe McIntyre
results.brief_description: Multi-award-winning film ‘The Telegram Man’ poignantly depicts the human cost of war in its portrayal of relationships impacted by the vicissitudes of wartime. Featuring restrained but deeply emotional performances from some of Australia’s finest screen actors (Jack Thompson, Gary Sweet and Sigrid Thornton), this is a powerful film about loss, grief and duty.

holdings.name: MOV file H264; ACMI Digital Access Copy - presentation

results.title: [Cinesound Review 1950-1965]
results.brief_description:
This film contains excerpts from Cinesound Review, a news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. The film features a number of different clips from newsreels between 1950 and 1965.

The first section, titled ‘1950 Melbourne Cup’, shows the horse race at Flemington Racecourse, photographed by Ron Horner. The film includes close-ups of people in the crowd, and commentary of the race as Comic Court wins. This is followed by a section titled ‘Scone Rodeo: Bronchos (sic) on the Bust’, featuring footage of a horse rodeo in Scone, New South Wales.

The third section, titled ‘Fur Flies: Battling Budgerigar K.O.’s Cat’ features a playfight between two pets, a ginger cat and a budgerigar. In the fourth section we see ANZAC Day parades in Melbourne and Sydney, preluded by the title ‘ANZAC: Nation’s Homage’.

The fifth section is titled ‘Skiing: Day and Night Fun at Mt. Buller’, with commentary by David Low. It features children learning how to ski and social activities in the resorts, including bands and dancing. This is followed by an excerpt called ‘Clark Well Ahead’, showing the motorcar race at the 1965 British Grand Prix, won by Jim Clark.

The film ends with a cartoon called ‘Local Boy Makes Good: A Story with a Moral’ and three feature film trailers: ‘The Counterfeit Traitor’ (1962), ‘Pollyanna’ (1960) and ‘Mein Kampf’ (1960).

results.title: My City Walkabout
results.creator_credit: Emmie Seaton, Mateuse Pingol and MatEm Productions
results.brief_description: ‘My City Walkabout’ is a film with a French New Wave aesthetic that follows an Aboriginal man searching for his place in modern Australian society. Set in the man’s dream, the film explores magic realism sequences to illustrate the protagonist’s desire to alter his reality and ultimately find his identity.

results.title: Rippled
results.creator_credit: Darcy Prendergast, All India Radio and Oh Yeah Wow Pty Ltd
results.brief_description:
‘Rippled’ features a range of animation techniques - including light painting - to evoke a dystopian nighttime urban landscape of eerie beauty being explored by a creature of ambiguous identity.
Animators: Josh Thomas, Michael Greaney, Josh OKeefe, Donna Yeatman, Darcy Prendergast, Seamus Spilsbury, Andrew Onorato
Music: Martin Kennedy (All India Radio)

results.title: Burger Burger
results.creator_credit: Gavin Jun Jie Tan and Huang Shicong
results.brief_description: The story of a marooned explorer who meets some local wildlife, with a scary - but eventually serendipitous - outcome. This colourful, fast-paced short animation won Best Animation at the Singapore Short Film Awards 2011.

results.title: In the air is Christopher Gray
results.brief_description:
A series of unfortunate events leads to disaster when young Christopher Gray tries to impress the girl of his dreams.
Written, directed and animated by Felix Massie.
Cast: Andy London, Peter Ahern, Justin Cassano, Carolyn London, Ian Miller, Erica Perez
Soundtrack: Joe Paine
Sound design and mix: Marty O’Brien
